description: From Middle English composen, from Old French composer (“to compose, compound, adjust, settle”), from com- + poser, as an adaptation of Latin componere (“to put together, compose”), from com- (“together”) + ponere (“to put, place”).

verbs.description: compose (third-person singular simple present composes, present participle composing, simple past and past participle composed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make something by merging parts. [from later 15th c.]
examples: The editor composed a historical journal from many individual letters.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make up the whole; to constitute.
examples: A church is composed of its members.

entries.meaning: (transitive or intransitive) To construct by mental labor; to think up; particularly, to produce or create a literary or musical work.
examples: The orator composed his speech over the week prior.
Nine numbered symphonies, including the Fifth, were composed by Beethoven.
It's difficult to compose without absolute silence.

entries.meaning: (sometimes reflexive) To calm; to free from agitation.
examples: The defendant couldn't compose herself and was found in contempt.

entries.meaning: To arrange the elements of a photograph or other picture.
To settle (an argument, dispute etc.); to come to a settlement.
examples: By trying his best to compose matters with the mullahs, he had sincerely shown that he did not seek a violent collision  […]

entries.meaning: To arrange in proper form; to reduce to order; to put in proper state or condition.
examples: In a peaceful grave my corpse compose.

entries.meaning: (printing, dated) To arrange (types) in a composing stick for printing; to typeset.
